instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b Not powering up
threads.message:
[FONT=verdana, geneva, lucida, lucida grande, arial, helvetica, sans-serif][COLOR=#000000]I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. with liquid spill on the wireless card. Nothing on the board. The board has a green light on the charger and it does charge the battery when the battery is not full but starting ( NO fan spin no video no 5v on s5 rail)[/COLOR][/FONT]

[COLOR=#000000][FONT=verdana]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12v
pp342, 3.42[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=verdana]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=verdana]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0v ( is it present when the machine is off???)

the question is Do i Need to have 5v on the pp5vs3 rail for the board to get 5v on the pp5vs5 rail?

thank you [/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b Not powering up
threads.message: Disconnect airport first of course. Are you using a real 85W charger? You can also let the battery charge up to a few lights on the indicator. Disconnect keyboard and power on the board by shorting <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> once the battery has some charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b Not powering up
threads.message:
Yes original power supply nothing connected to the board and battery fully charged 

thank you
